author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
.
Assuming we're talking about fairly typical rock, pop and Hip Hop then this 3 part strategy covers a lot of ground

1) Make sure the EQ is as balanced as you can get it - most of your perceived loudness comes from the arrangement and mid range focus (2k to 8k). Too much low end will sound bad when you limit. Make sure the relationship between 80, 160 and 320 makes sense (think of them a little like fundamental, 1st and 2nd harmonic).

2) Consider shaving snare transients (and maybe kick transients) with a clipper. This spreads that peak energy harmonically across the spectrum, keeping energy, hiding in the noisey nature of snares and lets the limiter work less hard (I like SIR Standardclip - $25, great metering and responds intuitively)

3) Pro-L2 on the settings below is a great start point for clean and predictable limiting, raising input gain until you get the desired level

author: Rollmottle
content:
I have a couple distinct phases of my workflow. The “technical” phase let’s call it, is all about letting my brain objectively search for the very specific kinds of things that are distracting within the mix at hand. This is much more of a thinking and corrective process than it is a feeling one, even though feeling and taste is 100% involved. This part of the process is to get the mix on a more solid foundation if needed.

The next phase is where I want to actively NOT be thinking at all. This is why I do the first part separately. I want to be FEELING the music in this phase and not be taken out of it by the vocal resonance at 1.8k at 1:35 in the bridge. I want to turn that part of my brain off so I can focus on the music, the feeling, the lyrics, the intent, the song and try to find where (or if) I can elevate or reveal or better frame the heart of what’s there. This is meant to be the flow state, moving intuitively and viscerally based on what’s coming out of the speakers. This is where efficiency in toolset matters -- where an extremely efficient human-computer interaction matters, where knowing your tools cold matters. I want to reduce latency between feeling and move and I don’t want anything to get in my way. 

So to answer your question: I think about ways to continue to be able to access and preserve that crucial flow state during the time where it matters the most. And it can manifest a million ways that aren’t directly related to mastering at all: taking a walk, working out, doing a J, listening to a new record, checking Discord, unplugging, whatever. And yes, sometimes it also means refining my template or my Streamdeck shortcuts or creating a new preset.

author: BatMeckley
content:
To second matt, most everyone I’ve seen who had a great “come up” started because someone liked a record they did with a small shitty unknown band. My first real big break came from helping out with and swapping songs with a college buddy, who then managed to get a record deal, and I got to come up and help a little bit and meet with their producer. After a brief stint in Australia in another band, like Matt Rad, I relentlessly (but respectfully) kept reaching out to the producer to see if there was any toilets I could clean or any help at all I could give him, or even if he was just available for a quick lunch and could I play him some bands I was working on.  After a couple months he brought me in and taught me melodyne saying “if you get good at this you’re going to own a house someday”. 

This post is coming from inside the house. 

I think the mistake a lot of people make is they reach out hoping that someone can help them, and not with the intent of how they can help the person they’re reaching out to. I never planned to be Vocal Producer to the Stars ™️ but it turned out it was a job that needed to be done that other people didn’t want to do, and I started to get passed from big name producer to bigger name producer, and then I got enough clout to actually be the middle sized name producer. But it starts with going “hey, what do YOU need” and not “hey can you help ME”

author: sethearnest
content:
I do a Save-As at any point in a production or mixing phase that I think “this feels really great to me right now in this moment” and/or if I do some sort of major change to arrangement, massive tonal change, etc. I’ll also print that version to use as my new “ref” as a mix comes together. Sometimes you make one decision then head down a cascade of changes from that one decision. Sometimes it’s great; other times you go back to the previous “this feels great to me in this moment” version and realize your cascade is a disaster. 

Like @samvalentine , Save Copy In is only for sending sessions for me.

author: chrissorem
content: Strange I find most people hearing tuning/intonation better with a bass element in the mix. If I’m tuning multiple vocals, I tune the lead and mute other melodic instruments that might be distracting. Then tune  doubles to the lead, tune  the harmony with the lead, tune the  doubled harmonies to the tuned harmony and so on. I try to move fast not worrying about it being perfect and I then solo all the vocals together the see how they feel or put them back in the mix. As I’m working on the song if something feels off I’ll scope it out then. For me It’s very easy to get into a hyper tuning mode where everything sounds like it needs tuned if I obsess over it. I find it better to do a broad stroke pass and fine tune things as needed

author: cian riordan
content:
So! @BoozleBAM! I took a gander and you’re in pretty good shape! I think you’re going to hit some sonic limitations with the quality of your signal path and the cymbals you are using, but the drums sound pretty good and the space you’re in isn’t terrible. Some notes:
- Your cymbal mic'ing approach might be a little overly comprehensive. Its nice to have spot mics on each cymbal, but might be worth trying a more traditional overhead approach. It’ll help get a more natural image of the kit and will likely free up some microphones for other spot positions on the drum set or in the room.
- Your kick drum sounds like a basketball. Theres a few things you can do with tuning, but I would firsttry having some dampening inside. If you like them sounding wide open, then consider taping some felt or paper towels to the inside of the drum shell, at least half way around the interior circumference of the shell. It’ll help quash that bouncing basketball sound.
- Your snare sounds beefy! Obviously, its going to be song and arrangement dependent, but on its own it sounds like you could voice it a little higher to get it to crack a little more.
- If you free up some mics by simplifying your cymbal setup, consider having a mic at the ‘crotch’ position… picking up the center of the kit. It can be useful for anchoring the mono signal of the drums and gives you something nice to potentially squash or distort down the road.
- Your room mics sound pretty good with the right EQing!

author: cian riordan
content:
I started getting serious about recording while I was in college (studying chemistry). I was playing bass in a band at the time and I was the only one that had any sort of decent recording equipment. I found myself being the guy recording all of the band's demos before we went into a 'proper studio'. Eventually, we realized my demos were sounding better than the ones we paid other people to record! Meanwhile, I started assisting (for free) at a local small recording studio and met a really great mentor. The studio was small and its business was mostly weekend warrior type stuff – nobody really notable. That being said, it was a working studio – and booked almost 6-7 days a week. The producer was the big fish in the small pond and had a great repeat clientele. Most of the music was not my cup of tea – but this proved to be a good thing as I was exposed to all sorts of different styles and it allowed me to be comfortable in genres of music which I normally wouldn't gravitate towards. It just made me comfortable around music and musicians in general.

Once I graduated and decided I wasn't going to use my chemistry degree, I ended up helping the producer build a bigger studio complex from the ground up. I learned an insane amount of stuff during this period – whether it was researching which Pro Tools system we would need to helping design the wiring layout to actually implementing it all. Ultimately, after months of hard work (and lots of borrowed money) the studio was complete and it was ready for business. I worked here for 2 years or so until I got introduced to Eric Valentine through former Street To Nowhere guitarist Matt Radosevich in Los Angeles. He needed a new full-time assistant and so I hopped at the opportunity and moved to LA – leaving behind the studio and crew I helped build (they're still going today and they're doing great).

author: cian riordan
content: Tuning drums to the key of the song can sound amazing if you have the time and diligence to manage it — very difficult if it’s a one person operation. Also I’d rather a Tom have its own pitch in drum universe than being slightly sharp or flat to something in the key — that will sound even more distracting.

author: Slow Hand
content:
**Other ideas:**

Call and response between the players.
Give the players big unison hits that they can land on together.
Everybody takes a big rest.
Everybody takes a big rest except one player.
Everybody plays the melody in unison.
Hocket the melody between players.
Swap roles among the players (Guitar plays like a drummer, drummer plays melodically, bassist sings).
Counterpoint.
Play dynamically.
Dynamics that rise or fall over two or more bars.

author: lystell
content:
Sure, you’re probably right. I’d like to add some thoughts if it’s ok though. 
I thought it might be healthy to ask the question why I make music? What in making music is the most exciting to me? What Outcome am I expecting?
I too enjoy many parts of making music and I wanna be better at all of them. I do though have to remind myself that people spend their life learning time and effort to play only one part of the process, say bass.
What are my expectations? Am I fine with making a finished record, regardless how it turns out (I’m satisfied with the fact that I did all of it). Or do I have the expectation that the drum part to be NFL, the mix to be Wimbledon or the lyrics to be Dylan. Then I have to be either be patient enough to know that it will likely happen when I’m old and grey, or that I maybe should focus on fewer tasks. 
Writing melody, lyrics, singing, playing guitar, recording/engineering, mixing….. That’s a lot of abilities/capacities to learn/explore. A long the road you will have many needs being met. Consolation, support, validation, love, and more. An online forum can be a wonderful thing. In this case an extraordinary thing. It can’t though meet all your needs and replace the presence of humans around you. One small example is the phenomenom that it only takes for a person to enter the room when you’re working on something and instantly, even without words you know suddenly what you feel about it yourself. 
It’s a challenge to cooperate but learning and doing is most often more effective and fun doing it together. 
I have got the best advice in this forum. That doesn’t equal that I will write the best song tomorrow.
I’m trying to be aware of my expectations. Of this forum, of myself, the process, the outcome..
Embracing the contribution of others is a wonderful feeling. Play the part you enjoy the most.

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
When you sing, you want to be as relaxed as possible. The moment it starts to feel like it hurts STOP. Breathing correctly also helps. When you breathe in, push your stomach out. You’re effectively getting the air into your diaphragm which is where you want the power to come from. When you breathe in, kinda do it like you’re yawning. That opens up the back of your throat (pause). Ideally you want your throat to act as a channel that your voice comes out of. If you look in the mirror while you sing, there’s this little bulge in your throat (like an Adam’s apple) - that’s your larynx. You wanna keep that either centered or moving down. You’ll notice if you start singing and you’re straining, it’ll start moving up, closer to your chin. That’ll eventually hurt your voice.

Sorry if that’s a lot. I have more lol but I just wrote what I could off the top of my head.

Edit: oh yea! When you’re warming up, do lip trills or hum into a straw! Like a 5 note scale going up and down. Starting from the bottom of your range to the top (before I starts to hurt).  That gets the sound to what’s called the “mask” of your face. That also takes the stress off of your throat when you sing.

author: Eric Martin
content:
room tone and proximity effect are why.

If you have a great sounding room you can back off the mic and you’ll introduce room tone, or the sound of the room into the mic’d bleed.

If you have a dead room you can back off with this happening less, there will still be some sound there, but less.

A lot of studio mics are used with the Cardioid polar pattern depending on the source and what sound you need for the recording, getting closer to the mic can introduce more low end from what’s know as proximity effect, this can exaggerate the way the lows are heard from the source on a record.

If you find yourself EQing out low end, maybe back off the microphone a bit and experiment with how far and hear how much room gets introduce as you add more preamp gain when you do this.

It’s a choice, and a decision, learn why you like it and where.

Omni mics have little to no proximity effect, figure 8 also have some proximity effect, use this to your advantage.

author: sethearnest

Depending on a large list of caveats (tempo, singer, producer, rest of arrangement etc etc), you could also extend the "s" and make it a part of the rhythmic interest of the hook as a pickup to the downbeat. Extend it earlier to the & of 4 of the previous bar so it'd be | / / / , sssss | TAY

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I usually get a backbeat or 4 on the floor going, even if it's subtle. But I've had a lot of great songs written to just that, then drums are built around it later. tbh if you have that and you're having trouble getting drums to work later, it's usually not because you didn't get proper drums in there. If the song is great and there's a basic beat, you're pretty much set. a simple backbeat goes a long way.

As I've said before, I think the two essential parts of a song are not actually piano/vocal or guitar/vocal but instead beat/vocal. chords are obviously important, usually. But melody against rhythm is primarily what people move to and remember. if you can sing and clap it, you've probably got something.

author: Slow Hand
content:
What are you doing for chords? A common pitfall of static arrangements is getting locked into the same four bar chord loop. Sometimes you've got to break out of that. Start there, even if it's as simple as telling a different story with your chords over eight bars versus four bars.

Play with the harmonic rhythm of your chord changes. Some very basic examples:
1. Instead of a single chord every measure, alternate between one chord per measure and two chords per measure.
2. Hold on a single chord for six measures and then do a cadence with a quick succession of chords on bars seven and eight.
3. Take your progression and play it at half the speed (a four bar progression becomes an eight bar progression).

I know you said you're just making beats right now, but chords or a melody are going to inform and motivate your "players" and show them what to do. There needs to be some "meat" to the song for them to react to. If you don't like the melody you can mute it later. But give your "players" something to react to.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Of course depends on the tempo, part, sound of the drums, aesthetic of the track - but a few things that have worked in different scenarios for me:

Create the impression of some distance to walls by sending snare (start there, maybe add other mics) to a short stereo delay. Often something like 90ms on one side, 120ms on the other. Feel it out on one side, then add some time to the other.

Try adding some fake distance to your existing room mics with a simple delay with no feedback (there’s a Steve Albini drum video on YouTube where he demonstrates this). You can delay both sides equally, or solo one side, delay it til it feels good/sounds cool, then do the other. Anything from 12ms-around 23 seems to work. From there things start to become more like a slap, but than can be cool too.

Smash up your existing rooms a bit, or a lot. Omnipressor, Devil Loc, UAD Zener, decapitator, Rough Rider (free), Arousor/Distressor in nuke, Lo-Fi. 

Send to a gated verb - Cian shared a drum session a while back with a short VintageVerb preset that’s often useful. RMX16 Non-Lins can be good too, although it’s easy to bring things into 80s territory this way.

Send to a short room verb like ocean way, SP2016, Pro-R, Valhalla Room, Raum. Sometimes from close mics, sometimes from overheads, sometimes just slapping it straight on room mics. A little distortion (Decapitator, Devil Loc) after is often helpful.

With all of these solutions, the thing that seems to help them gel with the rest of the real kit is drum bus processing - compression and/or saturation.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Double M/S is by default a Quadraphonic matrix output. LRLsRs.  Quad files are an odd format, but you can scale them to a standard SMPTE surround file. L R C Lfe Ls Rs....   but use audio black in C and LFE imo. You could push LR to C and all to LFE but you might lose mono compatibility with folddown. 

Dispite what they say...   Don't over bloat your deliverable with everything and the kitchen sink. It's sort of unnecessary if you include the natural matrix output of the format. Preserving the Quad output in a standard SMPTE poly wav would be the cleanest thing.  Just make sure you're also using UCS metadata formats.  These days that's a big feature for sound designers.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
One of the reasons I think this way is because anytime you EQ something, you are introducing phase shifts around either side of the frequency you're using. I find low end to be particularly sensitive to phase shifts. Phase shifts blur sound slightly, which is particularly bad for the low end instrument that you want to be punchy and full. 

While EQ may boost your overall low end, often times you are losing punch and clarity at the same time.

author: lystell
content:
I totally agree. I have a lot experience trying to bring a song from start to finish and have been in probably every pothole out there. 

The workflow/mindset that has made the biggest difference to me, is kind of forgetting about mixing (like parallel this and that, automation or even buses) for the writing/recording part of the process. 
Focusing solely on arrangement. Record as good as you can those parts you think does the song well. 
Arrangment and balance gets you so very far. 
Then it’s a good idea to tidy up the project and prepare it for next phase. 
Agreeing that it’s a good idea to leave the song for a while and when you decide to mix, you listen with a mixing mindset. Like what can be enhanced, cleaned up, sound designed etc.
What I see as a luxury in this way of doing, is that you can always add or remove stud that you suddenly feel.

Cymbals:
- These were honestly the toughest part of the sound. I ended up bussing all your cymbal mics and treating them as a set. author: hyanrarvey
content:
For me if I were you. I’d have done it like this

1.scratch out the song with programmed drums and focus on making sure the click track is right. Do as many tempo changes and push and pulls till it feels right. Map out the song to where it feels exactly how you want it. Do minimal programming to get the idea’s across you don’t have to go wild with velocities. Since your a drummer you should know what your playing and it’ll make it way easier

2. Track rthym guitars and bass and comp them while you track 

3. Track vocals

Either tune em your self or comp them like crazy whatever makes you happy 

4. Track leads 

5. Track drums 

6. Mix it

So, for pro tools I assign the three extra buttons for each one of the tools, and then chording the top two buttons gives me multitool in the instances that’s useful.  

Then my left hand is on asdfg for fades and moving the boundaries of clips (WAY faster than multi tool to just click in the middle of a region or at the zero crossing of an audio file and hitting A)

author: cian riordan
content:
Process/Theory:
I see lots of people’s previous responses say they begin with getting the overheads to sound great and then start blending in close mics. If the drums were recorded by someone who knew what they were doing, with a good sounding kit, in a nice room — this would be a wonderful way to approach things. However 90% of the time that’s not the case with tracks that come my way. So I’m solving fro two problems — making the drums:
1) The foundational rhythm element. It doesn’t matter how good tonally your drums sound, they need to fill specific duties to carry the rhythm of the song. This is usually problem solving with phase within the elements of the drum set and then mostly getting the kick and snare to sit right around the rest of the instruments. Literally getting the right transients in the right frequency ranges — agnostic of ‘tone’ and ‘vibe’.
2) The sense of space for the mix. The drums are a huge part of this… and the foundation for the aesthetic of a mix. Is it a tight space? Big verby snare? This is all great, but will rarely deal with this stuff until #1 is taken care of. So my process starts with close mics.

After poking around and listening to the close mic various options to get a sense of what I’m working with, I’ll start with getting everything in phase. Solo the kick drum mics and get those in phase with each-other. If they don’t add up, I’ll start playing with HP filters at various Q’s to try and get things closer. You’d be surprised what you can get away with even when things are even 90 degrees out. Then, I’ll start introducing more spot mics (snare, toms, HH) and start getting things in focus with just phase flips. By the time you get to the overheads and rooms, you should have all the spot mics in phase with each-other so then you can get a better sense of how the overheads are going to play into the game.

author: ALXCPH
content:
I agree mostly with this! I’ve been playing instruments for 20 years and have made a living from it. If you want to get good, it is aactually pretty easy and anyone can do it with the right mindset and patience(key word here). Firstly stop playing on and off, just play as often as you can preferably every day if not every other day.  Stop worrying about scales chords and theory, and just play. Learn as many songs as you can, like really learn them. Your ear will get better at picking up details, like groove and technique over time, so just learn the songs as good as you can and then move one to the next. Try and make it through a 1000 songs over the next few years. You don’t need to remember them, just get through them and move on. You will pretty quickly start recognising patterns in music and realise most music is made up of the same few combinations of chords notes and so on. At this point I would recognise learning some theory, so that you will be able to name those musical patterns be it cadences, notes, chords, extensions and so on.  Then depending on what with your playing. This next bit is super important. If you don’t care about playing in bands or performing for people then you can do this whole thing by your self. But if you want to play with real people on a stage or a basement then you need to spend time playing with people as much as you can. Learn some songs go to a jam session either at a local pub, church or what ever you have in your city. Having friends who play is also great as you might be able to get a chance to play with them regularly, maby even make a band. When learning a song, make sure you can play it all the way through with either a metronome or a drum track before moving on. Video taping also helps to be able to get an objective look/listen to your playing so you will know, what you need to be mindful of. 

Keith Jarrett the pianist learned one 1000 songs the first year for a restaurant piano gig before he was known or good.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I love (trying) to explain this because it always makes me think of new things to try.

You can stereoize a sound using lots of techniques, the main three being pitch, delay, and phase. Often times your favorite plugins will do combos of these, so flipping the phase on one side will sometimes kill some of your wideness.

It's worth doing a google, but something like a flanger is simply duplicating the signal and micro delaying one of them at a variable rate. So the duplicated signal might oscillate between 2-20 milliseconds, which makes that crazy flanger sound. If you take that duplicated signal and run it through an aggressive filter (which will introduce some phase shift) and that's what a phaser is. 

You can play with multiple duplicate signals, flipping phase on one side and getting wild effects. You can play with pitch on the delayed signal and start getting an effect we call "chorus." But of course, each of these types of effects are just combinations of fundamental ways to manipulate audio. Many combos are possible!

Hooray sound design!

Also, I would love @Slow Hand to correct and expand, since I know he (and many others on here) are REAL sound design nerds.

author: Will Melones
content:
Oh yeah, for sure. It’s easy to overdo it, and satisfying enough that sometimes you don’t know in the moment.

Ultimately you can be 100% in the right speaker or 100% in the left speaker, and pushing beyond that is tempting the gods. As far as I can conceive it, any process that attempts to widen a signal that’s already entirely decorrelated must have the potential to reintroduce some correlation. Thinking again of the ping pong delay, is there really anything wider than that?

I was doing a lot of M/S mix buss widening stuff a few years ago, and I realized that it could do some pretty weird shit to panned vocals and the like. While it feels like you can just ‘turn up the sides’, you’re really doing something unnatural to the center, too, and the relationship between channels. Like you’re choosing select bits of a sound to turn up, but only the bits of that sound that don’t have anything in common with the other speaker. This is a lot of rambling just to say that there’s clearly a point of diminishing returns, and maybe the solution is to pan something else less wide to create contrast.

author: LAPhill
content:
Are you looking for resources on writing/production, or mixing? Just like with the record side, there's so much noise from bedroom composers and people that have zero real-world experience. And as Ruairi is always saying, even the people with real success often can't teach what they know. Maybe I'm a bit cranky after an 8 hour delay at the airport yesterday, but Spitfire has gotten quite good at creating "tutorial" videos that are thinly veiled advertisements, and many of their libraries are the equivalent of one-knob plugins or CLA vocals. Selling paint-by-numbers solutions to naïve kids who want to get into scoring (They're far from the only ones guilty of this). But to focus on some of the channels I think are actually worth their salt:

8-Bit Music Theory: https://www.youtube.com/@8bitMusicTheory/videos
Can be a bit basic at times, but he talks a lot about structure which, IMO, is becoming a lost art in modern scoring.

Anne-Kathrin Dern: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWJg1w7F3PKPbSpEF2YOejVjWAg-KcM3Z
Not the biggest name out there, but she has a no-bullshit way of explaining things about orchestration and theory that is clear and concise. As far as "teachers," I think she's a good one.

Alan Meyerson Waves Sessions: https://youtu.be/h9jZqn5lnw4
I hesitate to include this. I know for a fact that Alan swapped out a bunch of his go-to plugins to make everything a Waves product. I haven't watched this in awhile, but it's a good insight into how he sets up a big mix session and why he makes some of his decisions. He's also playing to the camera/audience some, so this is a your-mileage-may-vary recommendation.

McGowen Soundworks: https://www.youtube.com/@McGowanSoundworks/featured
Phil knows his shit, and goes pretty deep breaking down a few actual mixes, which is pretty rare to find.

If I think of others, I'll report back. Hope that helps

author: Will Melones
content:
Hmm I’ve always handled this with the subtlest amount of fader automation I can get away with. Just enough of a dip on the sustained note so the focus shifts to the incoming line, and the lyrics are intelligible, but without making the first line trail off (unless that’s the desired effect).

I think of those musicals where there’s a big chorus and everyone’s singing different counter lines on top of one another. It’s like a chaotic puzzle, but what you realize is that the lyrics to the counter lines are all lines you’ve heard earlier in the show. So your brain can fill them in without really listening, and the arranger’s job is to use a spotlight to continually move your focus to the most important melody at any given moment.

author: Deleted User
content:
Mixing and mastering can mess up carefully crafted arrangements/recordings. In order for someone to give it a go with you, it would take some level of trust that they won’t be getting back a fucked up mix. 

I’m a producer that occasionally mix for others, and I found it the easiest to get in on earning people’s trust by offering other things first. Record them, or tune vocals for them and then let them know you also mix. People are more likely to record with someone they don’t know yet than to have someone they don’t know mix or produce their stuff.

As a producer, I’d deny free offers from new mixer to mix what I’m working on unless I have heard their work and I like them. I’ve had people ask if I need mixing and offered through their relationship with the artists- it always came back fucked… at least so far. So try to get in with producers through offering other stuff like engineering in writing sessions. Comp and tune the demo vocals you got from the writing session, if you do a great job they’ll more likely to give it a go with you. Don’t ask too early, make sure you build a good rapport with them first. Vocal tuning can fuck things up just as bad as mixing, so try to find things where you can just do it (e.g. you just recorded vocals for someone) over asking people if they need their vocals tuned.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
Bit of an aside (still bus related) and not sure if this is the best way of doing it, but I tend to route all musical elements (non-drums and percussion) to a bus, all drums and percussion to a second bus, and all vocals to a third bus. 

I then have a further bus where I bring the musical elements together with the drums and perc, so “instrumental”.

And then my final bus which I label “all” that pushes through to the mix bus.

This way I have plenty of options for automation, levelling, compression, and even FX like whacking EchoBoy or the Echorec on it and going nuts for transitions and bridges etc.

It’s possibly not the best way of doing it but it works great for me at the mo. My template for writing / prod and mixing is just set up that way now.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Here goes…
Million ways to skin this cat. I’ll give you food for thought.

1. At least double track. My personal goal, is to get the sound to be as awesome and huge and perfect with 1 pair of guitar tracks doubled, with 1 mic on an amp. That’s the ideal scenario for me. That said There are people that sum 4 mics down to 1 signal on a mixer and it sounds amazing.  

2. The more performances  you add of the same part, the more blurry it will sound.if you need different textures, consider recording a DI so it can be blended in with your amp in any manner of your choice, either reamping, distorting with a plugin, whatever. (Check phase)

3. I like when the left and right are *subtly* different, no drastically different. You hear “the left and right being different is what makes something wide”
This is true. But I loathe when it’s so different it feels lopsided.

How do we address this? 

-double track using the same guitar so the tuning and intonation is most similar 

-change the amp head but keep the same cabinet/speaker so the overall EQ is similar but my the gain structure is different

If you use 2 different guitars, consider the scale lengths. This will change subtle intonation things, for better or worse.

author: cian riordan
content:
I would tell them there's a few things to consider when pressing vinyl:
1) Mastering is especially important as it’s the real bridge between the music and the mechanical production of the record. I had the great pleasure of mastering a few records for vinyl with Doug Sax (give him a google) and there’s a lot more to the process than modern mastering for digital services. They will actually cut the acetate disc which will be what manufacturers use to make the metal stamper that actually molds the records. A lot of thought goes into this process such as the width of the grooves to accommodate bass frequencies, etc. If you want a good sounding record, there’s no way around working with a seasoned professional.

2) Side lengths are important, as is track order. The more music you put on a side of vinyl, the less fidelity it will have as a whole. There will be sacrifices in the manufacturing to accommodate all of the music, so it’s best to keep your side lengths under 20 mins. Closer to 15 mins per side is ideal sonically, but sometimes that means doing double records and that just gets expensive. Also the order in which the tracks play on each side plays a part. The songs at the beginning of the side have more bandwidth and less distortion… it basically diminishes the closer you get to the center. Whatever the last track on the side is will just sound worse. It’s a flaw in the medium… so think about that.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: __**TLDR**__ - So what to do practically in the real world? If I had a super fast and stable computer I would record, produce and mix at 96k. It’s subtly better in every way and you can introduce any of the “desirable” problems from lower sample rates at will. BUT BUT BUT….if there was even the tinniest chance that the rig would hiccup, or my drives would not access fast enough, or that I would have a glitch in a real session then I would absolutely start at 48k.

author: David Fuller
content: I don't consider it a good idea to work above 96 though, as you'll start introducing junk from switching power supplies, class D amps, noise shaping from D/A and A/D, etc into the program material. At lower sample rates it's effectively rolled out by extremely steep AA filters

author: Deleted User
content:
I don’t disagree with you, it’s definitely a common workflow in rnb hip hop and it’s how it’s done more often than not. But even then, rappers write verses with pen and rnb writers can sing on their own to write a song. The way I’ve been going about it is I ask if they have any lyrics at least- with people I have encountered the answer is almost always no. So as a producer, I don’t really have any context to work with. And I’ve tried- many times they end up really disconnected contextually even though they may sound right. 

If they are putting out a lot of volume that they just prefer to get halfway there then it’s a different story, but new artists with no music out yet or a few singles or one EP out having no lyrics or song on them is why I feel the way I do about “send me a beat” situation.

My perspective may not be as informed because haven’t gotten to work with a good rapper yet. Some of the people that I have tried to work with that insist on this approach don’t know how to work with fitting words into a bar unless they have drums.

Same with RnB- I like to work with keys or guitar in the room and build together from ground up. But my experience has often been people just don’t know what they want or don’t know how to write on their own. 

My frustration is- “can you at least tell me what’s on your mind?”. Whatever works, works. But if they don’t have any thematic vision then I can barely see it working out 😦

author: Zack Hames
content:
Not exactly. But pickups make the biggest difference tone by a long mile. 

Like others have said, if a guitar plays well and feels good to you, then go for it and then put nice ass pickups in it, and you’re golden. 

Other big “sound” considerations are scale length,  bridge style/material and nut material. Not to mention the strings themselves. 

Lighter guitars actually resonate / have more sustain usually, for obvious physics reasons that people ignored for a long time.

Copy is CTRL C 
Paste is CTRL C
Undo is CTRL Z
Redo is CTRL Y
Create a new audio channel is CTRL T (I think)
Create a new MIDI channel is CTRL SHIFT T (I think)
Create a new clip is CTRL SHIFT M while highlighting an area on the arrangement
To join clips together it's CTRL J
To group audio effects together it's CTRL G

To toggle automation view on the arrangement it's A ("Computer Keyboard" must be disabled in order to toggle.)
To toggle "Computer Keyboard" (this enables you to play notes on your typing keyboard), it's M
 
To save it's CTRL S (SAVE OFTEN!!)

author: Deleted User
content:
A couple questions about beatmaking/overdub workflow

I’m mainly making beats at the moment, meaning there is no song yet. I want to get good at more dynamic arrangement with linear development than vertical development (same instrumentation evolving with flowing energy vs parts in and out). I want it to have elements of interplay like a band playing in a room together, but fake it by overdubbing. 

I know dynamics can be achieved through taking things in and out or playing with different progressions/rhythm or moving octaves. From subtle to not so subtle changes. 

One solution I could think of is writing one instrument part at a time with the goal of developing the arc. But this comes with the challenge of vertical movement

I’m not sure if I have clearly explained what my issue is, but my process usually goes like this. 

1) I have one or two elements looping together
2) I pick up an instrument and search for ideas as it’s looping
3) once i have a solid idea, I’ll start  recording and improvise around the idea 
4) take has tons of mistakes, playing wrong notes and off timing. I pick some parts out and then drop them in. 

Now the problem is I can get some cool ideas and happy accidents, but it’s not usable yet. And it’s hard to figure out where I should drop these little bits and pieces because there is no context (aka vocal). And without context, I don’t know how I can move with intentions that will inform me what the next move is.

author: Slow Hand
content:
**Some More (cause you've got me thinking):**

Kick off the song with a bang.
Write a deliberate introduction. (This is big. It will give your record propulsion, confidence and purpose instead of dropping the listener into the middle.)
End the record in a conclusive and unmistakable way.

Everybody plays as soft as they can.
Everybody plays as loud as they can.
The louder you play the simpler the part has to be.
The softer you play the faster the part has to be.

Role play. Choose an emotion/mindset and embody that as the player: melancholy, furious, chaotic, childlike, meek.

Instrumental fills every few bars.
Take a solo. A short one.
Make some noise!

Listen to your song at different tempos.
Do a dramatic speed up or slow down - This will show you new aspects of your groove.

Unexpected part entrance.
Intro solo before the band enters.

Only two instrumental parts allowed. Be minimal and sparse.
Write a melody starting with the kick pattern.

author: shaunobi
content: I follow a similar approach when doing blue-sky producing - I'll prep song I like beforehand, splitting them into stems using UVR (which uses the best machine learning algos like Demucs v4 to split tracks). When people get there, I then play just the drums, or whatever, and we start layering other stuff on top of them. I speed it up, slow it down, use various parts, cut and paste - basically just to get something that inspires me during composition. Later, I'll come back with real musicians and actually record it, but this is a pretty powerful demo creation method, for me at least. Kinda fun to un-mute the OG track at the end and be like "yeah, it's been Interpol this whole damn time :)"

author: hendrick
content: in case this has been brought up before pls lmk but... what does it usually look like when you start to earn a meaningful back end on big songs you have producer/songwriting credits on? do you need management to get that money? what's the whole process like after the music is released? can someone ELI5?

author: Adam Thein
content:
I'd get in touch with a music lawyer who can help you make sure you have everything in place to collect all your back end - there's a lot of revenue sources you'll want to make sure you are collecting from.

Often you'll have had a producer agreement in place and a letter of direction that will be sent to the distributor/label so that if you have points on the master you'll be paid directly from them.

You'll also need to have a PRO/Publisher in place to collect songwriting royalties, and many folks have in place a publisher deal or publisher admin deal to collect those royalties on your behalf in exhange for a % of your royalty.  In my case I am set up with BMI in the US as my PRO and Publisher and have an admin pub deal with Sentric to collect in territories outside the US.

Also you'll want to be set up with SoundExchange to collect digital performance royalties (SiriusXM, iHeart, Pandora).  This often also involves the letter of direction that is kicked off with your producer agreement.

I'm probably forgetting something but I'd highly recommend talking with a music lawyer to get things set up and working for you.
